ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great overview of the history of urban protest from the 18th century to the modern day, as well as the interaction between protest and urban space

I learned to think about the built environment in a new way; how it connected to protests, riots, and general social and economic things occurring in cities. I love Alan Plattus, he is so smart and really engaging and helpful.
Learned about relations of urban space with revolution in protest

I learned a lot about particular urban revolutions about which I had previously known nothing or very little, but also about the structures of these insurrections and patterns and themes that can be traced through revolutionary movements more generally.
I began to start thinking more in terms of space and structures, which has been very impactful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Lots of case studies give a really good grounding. Maybe more consideration of how different protests have influenced one another

I loved the layout of this course, it allowed for more conversation and less lecturing. I also went in with minimal knowledge and although participating in conversations was more challenging for me without background knowledge, I was able to learn a lot through listening.
Longer class time so easy to lose interest in one subject

I really appreciated the overall format of this coursein particular, that students come to larger understandings about revolutions by studying particular episodes throughout history, which are in themselves all very interesting. At the same time, in some ways this was also a weakness, in that it could feel like there was little to no continuity from week to week. Other strengths included the readings, which I found too be particularly fascinating, and classes in general, which were always interesting and engaging (which is not always the case in such 2-hour blocks), with a good balance of lecturing by the professor and then student-led discussion.

The content is very interesting, but increasing the student engagement and participation would improve the course. The lecture style is good, but more class discussions would also be good to supplement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Interesting case studies and very visually engaging powerpoints that explore urban spaces and the choices of people who depict protest in these spaces either through photography or after the fact through drawing, prints etc
Yes, I think everyone should take a class with Professor Plattus, he is amazing.
Yes if youre looking for a low work course
No...despite it being a seminar, there was never any class discussion which dulled some of the incredible topics we covered

I certainly would recommend this course to other students. I primarily took it because of my major (architecture), but I would recommend it to any student, perhaps even particularly to those who know little about urban studies or the history of revolutions. As someone who came into the topic knowing very little, at no point did I feel lost, and I came to appreciate both what I learned and how much more I could learn, should I seek to. Also, the readings and discussions were enlightening, and the workload was relatively light.
Yes, I would highly recommend this class. It has changed the way I think about space, and I really enjoyed the content.
